page_details.post_title: Sabina Nessa’s ‘coward’ killer refuses to go to court for sentencing

page_details.article_body:
Koci Selamaj, 36, drove to London from his home in Eastbourne to carry out a premeditated attack on a woman with ‘extreme violence’ (Picture: PA)The sister of murdered primary school teacher Sabina Nessa has branded her killer a ‘disgusting animal’ for not facing up to his crime in court.
Sex predator Koci Selamaj has refused to come to the dock for a sentencing hearing today. 
The hearing went ahead in his absence as the court has no power to force him to attend.
Selamaj is facing a life sentence with minimum term of 30 years after admitting to murdering Sabina in an ‘extremely violent’ attack on September 17 last year.
The Albanian national, 36, targeted Sabina as she walked through Cator Park in Kidbrooke, southeast London, on her way to meet a friend.
CCTV footage captured the moment Selamaj attacked her by striking her over the head 34 times with a 2ft-long metal traffic triangle, before carrying her away unconscious.
He then pulled up her clothes, removed her tights and underwear and strangled her before covering her body in grass.
Sabina Ness was killed as she passed through Cator Park on her way to meet a friend on September 17 last yearThe court heard how two hours before the murder he had tried to contact his former partner to pressure her to engage in sexual activity.
After she refused he drove around Brighton ‘looking for someone to have a sexual encounter with’, said prosecutor Alison Morgan, QC.
He then ‘abandoned’ that plan and headed to London. He entered Cator Park shortly after 8pm and lay in wait for half-an-hour before Sabina arrived en route to The Depot bar where she was due to meet a friend.
Ms Morgan said it was ‘out of character’ for the year one Rushey Green Primary School teacher to be walking through the park after dark, but ‘she was running late and this was the quickest route to get to the bar’. 
She was ‘oblivious’ to her killer as he ran up behind her and attacked her on the path near a park bench.
The Old Bailey was told Sabina suffered approximately 34 bows to the head, inflicted with such force that pieces of the sign broke off. 
Selamaj’s actions afterwards were out of camera shot, but Sabina was not seen alive again.
Ms Morgan said the defendant asphyxiated her and removed her tights and underwear before trying to cover her body in grass. 
The prosecution allege there was a sexual motive for killing Sabina, even though there was no ‘positive’ evidence of a sexual assault.
Sabina’s body was discovered by a dog walker the next day who  at first thought he was seeing a ‘potato sack’.
Supporters from the Sabina Project outside the Old Bailey, central London (Picture: PA)Her death led to an outpouring of grief across the nation and led to renewed fury over violence against women in the UK.
Sabina’s family said their world had been ‘shattered into tiny pieces’ following her murder. 
Sister Jebina Yasmin Islam said in an impact statement read out in court: ‘Our sister Sabina was way more than just a sister, a daughter, a teacher, she was a life.
‘A life that didn’t deserve to be taken.
‘You snatched her without a second thought.
‘You are not a human, you are a disgusting animal.
‘Our parents are petrified any time one of their girls steps out the house now.
More: Crime newsTruly horrifying image shows swastika scratched on corpse of Ukraine rape victim
Woman who felt threatened on bus got help by dialling 999 and asking for pizza
Teacher who bombarded schoolboy with sexual WhatsApp messages is spared jail‘In our heads we have these images of what happened and what our sister must have felt when you decided to run after her and attack her when clearly she could not defend herself.
‘You planned this and made sure she was alone.
‘What makes us angry is that you left our sister’s body in an unrespectable manner to fulfil your filthy desires.
‘We just want answers as to why you killed her.
Koci Selamaj has been handed a life sentence  (Picture: PA)‘Why?
‘Our family will never forget what you did bit we will not let you take anymore from us.’
Selamaj had no previous convictions and no Interpol notices before he murdered Sabina.  But the sentencing hearing heard that the killer had a ‘recent history of violent behaviour towards his ex-wife’ Ionela Ghergishan, including putting his hands around her neck.
Ms Ghergishan said his behaviour towards her changed from May 2021 onwards, when he became ‘controlling, coercive and physically aggressive’.
She said she left him because she started to ‘fear for her life’, but on the day he killed Sabina, he had got in touch with her to pressure her for sex. 
The prosecution say Selamaj’s previous violent behaviour should be considered as an ‘aggravated factor’ in deciding his prison term, as well as his attempt to conceal the body. 
Ms Morgan also alleges the attack ‘did not come about on the spur of the moment’ and there was ‘significant planning’. 
Three days before the killing, Selamaj booked a room at the five-star Grand Hotel in Eastbourne, the town where he already had accommodation.
His reservation was for the night of September 17 and he arrived earlier in the day to check in. 
Members of the public attend a vigil in memory of Sabina Nessa and in solidarity against violence against women (Picture: PA)Sabina’ death sparked calls for more to be done to keep women safe (Picture: PA)Before leaving the park, he picked up pieces of the warning triangle and used wet wipes to clean a  bench near to where he launched his initial attack.
En route back to the south coast, Selamaj stopped in Tunbridge Wells in Kent and dumped the warning triangle in the River Teise.
Selamaj arrived back at The Grand Hotel at midnight and checked out in the morning before going to work at an Esso garage in Lewes.
He was arrested in the seaside town and charged days later.
He refused to comment in police interviews but when he was charged, the Albanian national said: ‘What will happen if I open up now and say everything.’
Mr Justice Sweeney said the ‘inevitable’ sentence would be life in prison, with a starting point of 30 years.
He adjourned the sentencing until 10am on Friday.
More: Crime newsTruly horrifying image shows swastika scratched on corpse of Ukraine rape victim
Woman who felt threatened on bus got help by dialling 999 and asking for pizza
Teacher who bombarded schoolboy with sexual WhatsApp messages is spared jailAddressing Selamaj, Sabina’s mother and father said: ‘As a parent, you would never have thought your child would die before you. Not in a way our Sabina died.
‘You had no right to take her away from us in such a cruel way.
‘The moment the police officer came to our house and told her she was found dead our world shattered into pieces.
‘How could you do such a thing to an innocent girl walking by, minding her own business. You are not a human being, you are an animal.’
Sabina’s death came months after the murder of Sarah Everard, sparking further calls for more to be done to make communities safer for women. 
Lisa Williams, head teacher of the school she worked at, described the ‘devastating’ impact of her murder on staff and pupils. 
She said Sabina was ‘a happy, hard-working’  teacher who had a ‘fulfilling career ahead of her’.
On Ms Nessa’s class of 30 students, she said: ‘For the rest of their lives, these young children will never be able to comprehend why someone murdered their teacher and the world in which they live is not safe for them to play in a park.’
Got a story? Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk. Or you can submit your videos and pictures here.
For more stories like this, check our news page.

page_details.post_title: Footballer’s heartbreaking final text messages as he was abducted by Russians

page_details.article_body:
Alexander Sukhenko was a gifted footballer who had come to his village’s aid after the Russian invasion of Ukraine (Picture: FC Kudrivka/Facebook/@Kudrivka)  The sister of a Ukrainian footballer killed along with their parents has revealed his final text messages before their bodies were found.
Alexander Sukhenko was seized by Russian troops who descended on their home in the village of Motyzhyn, 31 miles to the west of Kyiv.
The 25-year-old had joined his mother, Olga, the village head, and father, Igor, in supporting residents during the occupation.
His sister, Elena, paid tribute to the ‘treasure of the nation’, who had tried to allay her fears when the soldiers went to their parents’ home on March 23.
He had enrolled in the territorial defence and remained in Motyzhyn to help people living with bombardment, gunfire and shortages of essential supplies. The Liverpool fan, known as Sasha, transported aid to remote areas and collected orders for medicine which he passed to other volunteers.
The last texts he sent to his sister read, ‘they took mum’, before a final message assuring her: ‘Lena, we are fine, the phone will be turned off.’
The family had rallied behind humanitarian work from the outset of the invasion, remaining with their fellow residents as Russian forces attempted to advance on Kyiv from the north and west.
On February 27, the occupying troops took control of the village and are first said to have taken Alexander’s car before returning for his parents. 
Elena pleaded with her brother to leave but he remained at their home, telling her he was waiting for the couple to return.
Alexander Sukhenko excelled for his football club which wants to help trace and punish those responsible for his death (Picture: FC Kudrivka/@Kudrivka)The trio’s bodies were found dumped in a shallow pit just outside the village on Saturday, two weeks after they went missing, as Russian troops withdrew from the northern approaches to the capital.
They are said by Ukrainian officials and media channels to have been tortured and murdered by Moscow’s forces.
‘My parents and brother laid down their lives for our village, for our country,’ Elena said. ‘They did not give up, did not break, did not let down the honour and name of our family.
‘They are heroes. I’m so proud of them, I love them so much.
‘At the same time, I have such pain. I will never forgive anyone for this loss.
‘Sasha is the treasure of the nation. 
‘This is a worthy son, this is my soul, this is my best brother, this is a friend, an adviser, a man of his word and a real hero in this war.’
At her brother’s insistence, Elena, her husband and their child made the heartbreaking decision to leave the village for an undisclosed location, but they remained in daily contact.
Alexander Sukhenko with his parents Olga and Igor (Picture: FC Kudrivka/@Kudrivka)  ‘Little by little, people managed to leave, but some were shelled and it was a lottery,’ Elena said. 
‘Sasha coordinated the departure of people, formed humanitarian columns and gave out information on which hour was better to go. He was helped by some friends to gather information on the safest routes. 
‘He and his mother and dad continued to help people leave every day. 
‘They also distributed products to local residents, providing support and solving urgent problems within their capabilities.’
As Russian troops, including paratroopers and special forces, attempted to advance on the capital, the security situation in the village became increasingly perilous. But the family still managed to deliver aid and medicine, including to elderly neighbours on the street where they lived.
‘From the very beginning, he helped the village with his parents,’ Elena said.
‘They organized the processes so that the village functioned, because it was already difficult with the delivery of products and essential goods.
‘Then the orcs [Russian soldiers] came into the village. On the first day there were victims – innocent people.
‘There were constant explosions under which they woke up and fell asleep. The light was gone and it was scary to go outside during the day. 
‘Gunshots were heard everywhere. But it didn’t scare him for a second. 
‘He just said that my husband and I should have a Plan B, and that it would be better if we leave the village. I didn’t want to leave my family, it was very difficult to leave.’
Alexander Sukhenko was a talented footballer (Picture: FC Kudrivka/@Kudrivka)  Russian troops then went to the family home, where they initially took Alexander’s car before leaving. He had tried to speak to the occupiers, despite Elena warning him of the danger.
‘He said that if you speak to them confidently and adequately, then everything will be the norm,’ she said. 
‘I told them it was dangerous for them to stay home. But my parents and brother may have thought that they were no longer in much danger. 
‘How wrong they were.’
The soldiers, who are reported to have searched the house and also taken a phone, then returned a few hours later and took the parents.
‘First of all, they took our mother as the head of the village and as usual my dad went with her,’ Elena said. 
‘Sasha called me the last time and said that they had promised to bring them back alive and he would wait for them.
‘I asked if he should be somewhere else, I was very worried about him.’
At 15.36 she received the final text from her brother saying, ‘we are fine’ but that his phone would be switched off.
Alexander Sukhenko has been remembered for staying in his village to the last during the Russian occupation (Picture: Facebook/@boryspilTV) In the following days, villagers turned to social media as they made a desperate appeal for information about the trio’s whereabouts.
‘I fought to the last to save them, I knocked on all the doors, I screamed and asked for help,’ Elena said.
‘But what happened to my family you can see for yourself. These damned Russian bastards took everything from me, my sense, my happy life.’
Alexander played for the regional football club FC Kudrivka, which shared Elena’s account of her family’s final hours. 
Oleksandr Bruy, of the club’s press service, told Metro.co.uk: ‘Alexander and his parents are heroes. They helped many people and saved many residents of the village of Motyzhyn at the cost of their own lives.’ 
The club shared images of the forward and his parents under the dedication, ‘eternal memory and the kingdom of heaven’.
Alexander Sukhenko with his sister Elena who has remembered him as a ‘treasure’ of the Ukrainian nation (Picture: Elena Sukhenko/Instagram)The deaths of the family are among mounting evidence of war crimes perpetrated by Russian troops, which includes mass graves and bodies strewn by the roadside in towns and cities outside Kyiv.
Bucha, 15 miles to the north of the capital, has become synonymous with the atrocities, described as the worst since the Second World War. 
The family is said to have refused to have co-operated with the Kremlin’s forces, with Mrs Sukhenko posting a final defiant Facebook message on the day of occupation, warning of ‘scum’ in the village.
Anton Herashchenko, a Ukrainian interior ministry adviser, told Reuters: ‘The occupiers suspected they were collaborating with our military, giving us locations of where to target their artillery.
‘These scum tortured, slaughtered and killed the whole family.
‘They will be held responsible for this.’
Alexander Sukhenko has been remembered for staying in his village to the last during the Russian occupation (Picture: Facebook/@boryspilTV) The bodies, said by AP journalists to have been bound and blindfolded, were found as Ukrainian personnel cleared the area on Saturday.
The victims are believed to have been shot at close range. 
A fourth body close by in the sandy pit has not been identified but is believed to be that of a volunteer serviceman.
Moscow has denied committing war crimes and has said reports of civilians being killed are fabrications aimed at smearing Russia.
A ‘final farewell’ for the family is due to take place in the village today, with residents planning to gather near the home. 
In a post on Instagram, Elena said: ‘I want to sincerely thank everyone for your support, help, compassion and every kind word. 
‘The pain is unbearable, but thank you for everything. 
‘Heroes do not die.’
Do you have a story you would like to share? Contact josh.layton@metro.co.uk

page_details.post_title: Ketanji Brown Jackson becomes first black woman on Supreme Court after Senate confirmation

page_details.article_body:
Three Republicans crossed party lines in support of Judge Jackson (Picture: AP)The US Senate on Thursday voted to confirm Ketjani Brown Jackson, the first black woman to join the Supreme Court in its 233-year history. 
‘On this vote the yays are 53, the noes are 47, and this nomination is confirmed,’  Vice President Kamala Harris, said, acting in her role of Senate president.
Jackson secured three Republican votes and support from more moderate Democrats, marking somewhat of a bipartisan victory for President Joe Biden’s first nominee to the high court. 
Leading up to the vote, Senate Judiciary Chairman Dick Durbin called the moment ‘a glass shattering achievement for America.’To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web
						browser that
						supports HTML5
							video
‘Today, the members of this Senate have the opportunity to take a monumental step forward. We will vote to confirm a once in a generation legal talent, a jurist with outstanding credentials and a lifetime of experience and the first-ever African American woman to serve as Justice of the Supreme Court,’ Durbin, an Illinois Democrat, said Thursday. 
Earlier in the day, Jackson cleared a key test vote that limited the debate on her nomination and allowed for her confirmation to take place Thursday. 
A 53 to 47 vote to limit the debate on Judge Jackson’s nomination propelled her forward to confirmation. Three Republicans, Senators Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Mitt Romney of Utah, crossed party lines on the test vote. 
All three crossed party lines once again Thursday afternoon to confirm Judge Jackson. 
Jackson, 51, will be seated on the high court this summer, when Justice Stephen Breyer will retire after 22 years’ service. 
President Joe Biden embraces his Supreme Court nominee Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson as they watch the full US Senate vote on Jackson’s nomination (Picture: Reuters)While giving closing remarks before the vote, Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said it was a ‘wonderful,’ ‘joyous’ and ‘inspiring’ day for the Senate, Supreme Court and the rest of America. 
‘It’s been a dark two years with Covid . . . but even in the darkest times there are bright lights,’ Schumer said. ‘Today is one of the brightest lights. Let us hope it is a metaphor, an indication of many more bright lights.’ 
Speaking during her afternoon briefing, White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki said Biden had been engaging with Republican and Democrat Senators throughout the confirmation process.
‘This is a fulfillment of a promise the president made to the country. His time on the judiciary committee was defining for him and gave him historically exceptional preparation for what we would consider a smooth process, characterized by heavy engagement with both parties in the senate,’ Psaki said.

page_details.post_title: Teen made chilling ‘to-do list’ in plot to kidnap and kill ex using ‘murder toolkit’

page_details.article_body:
When officers arrested George they discovered the ‘sinister’ items she had collected (Picture: Sussex Police)A 20-year-old woman who created a ‘meticulous’ to-do list and a ‘murder toolkit’ has been jailed for plotting to kidnap, torture and kill her ex.
Sophie George was sentenced to 13-and-a-half years in prison at Lewes Crown Court after pleading guilty to attempted murder and possession of an offensive weapon in a public place.
George, who was 18 at the time, was said to be ‘consumed with revenge’ when she filled two bags with bleach, duct tape, forensic clothing, bin liners and lighter fuel.
She arranged for her victim and former lover to pick her up from her home in Brighton on October 10, 2020.
George insisted the 23-year-old drive her to a location where she collected two filled shopping bags.
She then tried to make him drive to a nearby park, at several points grabbing the steering wheel.
When he resisted, George pulled out a large serrated knife and threatened him.
The man managed to escape the vehicle, but George followed and a struggle ensued during which the victim managed to throw the knife into a bush.
Sophie George, 20, was sentenced to 13-and-a-half years in prison (Picture: PA)He then managed to call 999 but as he did George bit down on his finger to the bone.
A woman in flats overlooking the road saw George attacking him, and also dialed called 999.
A spokesperson for Sussex Police said when officers arrested George they discovered the ‘sinister’ contents of her bags.
He said these included ‘protective clothing, cleaning equipment such as bleach, duct tape and a Stanley knife – all linked to plans to kidnap, murder and ultimately cover up her crimes.’
A search of George’s address also revealed she had made a number of ‘to-do lists’, featuring plans including ‘drive to grave site’, ‘tourture (sic)’, and ‘walk him to site, kill and bury’.
Police were shocked when they discovered what was in George’s bags (Picture: Sussex Police )One of George’s  ‘meticulous’ to-do lists (Picture: PA)The court heard George had first met her victim when she was 17 at Moulsecoomb Station, when he was studying at the University of Brighton.
By the time of the attack, he had graduated and was working as a railway engineer in London.
Defending George, Graeme Wilson said that there had been an ‘imbalance’ in the pair’s relationship, pointing to her youth and what he said was a difficult home life.
‘She’s not mature, she’s frightened,’ he told the court. 
‘Frightened at the time, frightened of what she did and that’s expressed in the letter that Your Honour has before you today.
‘She’s frightened that she’s capable of doing what she did at that particular time.’
More: NewsBrit security guard accused of spying for Russia extradited from Germany
Bucha massacre shows Putin's desperation and 'should be a warning to us all'
Vladimir Putin's daughters to face sanctions from EU and US after Bucha massacreGeorge initially denied two charges of attempted murder and one of possessing an offensive weapon. She then pleaded guilty in May last year.
Prior to her latest hearing, the judge was handed a handwritten letter from George.
Following her sentencing, Detective Superintendent Jon Hull said: ‘This was a cold, pre-meditated plan to kidnap, torture and murder an innocent man, with clear steps to then cover up the crime.
‘I am in no doubt that George would have followed through with her hugely disturbing “to-do list” were it not for the victim overpowering her and the prompt response of our officers to bring her into custody.
‘I would like to thank the victim for his support in this investigation, the member of the public who called 999, and everyone involved – particularly Detective Paul Thomas, who was in charge of the investigation – for helping to take a dangerous individual off the streets.’

page_details.post_title: EV charger hacked with very fruity content on display instead of council website

page_details.article_body:
It was a bit of a shock for drivers trying to charge their cars on the Isle of Wight (Picture: AP / Google Maps)It was a normal day on the Isle of Wight when drivers attempted to charge their electric cars.
The island’s council has three charge points in Quay Road, Ryde, Cross Street, Cowes and Moa Place, Freshwater.
But some people had a bit of shock when they went to use the chargers and the screens – intended to show the council website – instead streamed pornography.
In a statement, the council apologised ‘to anyone that may have found the inappropriate web content and for any inconvenience from charge points out of action’.
It added: ‘We are saddened to learn that a third-party web address displayed on our electric vehicle (EV) signage appears to have been hacked.’
It said council workers would attend the chargers to make sure the issue is fixed and the pornography is no longer displayed.
The chargers were originally part of the ChargePoint Genie network, but had recently been transferred to the GeniePoint network.
The incident was first reported by the Isle of Wight County Press after readers raised the issue with the publication.
One of the chargers in question on the Isle of Wight (Picture: Google Maps)Owners of electric vehicles said they could not get a charger in the Cross Street Car Park in Newport to work.
The publication then reported the chargers were not working on Sunday, with continuing issues on Monday.
A council spokesperson said: ‘We are aware of the unreliability of some of the charge points in council car parks and will be replacing these with new charge points over the next few months.’

page_details.post_title: British ‘drug lord’ attacked man with pool ball for looking at him

page_details.author_container: Joe Roberts and Daniel Binns for Metro

page_details.article_body:
Darren Wall is now in tough New Bilibid prison facing claims of kidnap, extortion, drug dealing, assault, criminal damage and threats to kill (Picture: ViralPress)A suspected cocaine baron is behind bars in the Philippines after battering a reveller with a pool ball — then ­pointing a handgun at another as he chased him down the street.
Darren Wall, 44, was arrested by police in Manila who say they checked his mobile phone and found a ‘treasure trove’ of evidence of ­organised crime.
The east Londoner is now in tough New Bilibid prison facing claims of kidnap, extortion, drug dealing, assault, criminal damage and threats to kill.
Wall was on a date with wife Khanary Jane Abejo, 23, at the city’s Secret Door club when a local ‘looked at him the wrong way’, police said.
CCTV caught Wall hitting him over the head with the ball. He was bundled away but returned with a ball in a sock and smashed it in the man’s face. 
Outside, he punched another person then chased him down the street with a gun. He was arrested five weeks later.
Detectives allegedly found images of Wall posing with a handgun flanked by Filipino friends. Another is said to show him laughing with police on his payroll. 
Other images released by police show some of Wall’s alleged victims and their bloodied faces following the attacks.To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web
						browser that
						supports HTML5
							video
Darren Wall is on CCTV brandishing a gun outside the nightclub (Picture: ViralPress)Darren is seen on camera repeatedly punching the man before hitting him over the head with a pool ball (Picture: ViralPress)Darren Wall, 44, on a date with his wife Khanary Jane Abejo, 23, shortly before his arrest (Picture: ViralPress)They include a traumatised local who was too afraid to be named. ‘I only happened to be in the same areas as this guy but he started a fight with me,’ they said. ‘There was no reason and no provocation.
‘He pushed me, then shouted something. Then his men held me on the ground and put a gun in my mouth. He was shouting something like “don’t ever look at me again”. He said “I’ll kill you”. I really thought in that moment I would die.’
A police source said: ‘We have spoken to some of the alleged victims but there’s a very long queue of people.
‘He was behaving like a psychopath. The attacks were unprovoked — just because he felt like it or someone looked at him the wrong way.
Darren Wall posing with a gun with friends shortly before his arrest in Manila (Picture: ViralPress)This is the moment Darren Wall was arrested (Picture: ViralPress)Darren Wall following his arrest  (Picture: ViralPress)An alleged victim of Darren Wall in Manila (Picture: ViralPress)Another alleged victim of this East London ‘gangster’ (Picture: ViralPress)‘We have gathered a lot of videos and pictures from Darren’s phone and computer. It’s a treasure trove of evidence.’
In a video shot in the cramped cell he shares with violent inmates, he appears to have an injured arm and repeatedly refuses to answer questions. But at one point he insists: ‘I haven’t been hurting no one. They attacked me.’
Police Colonel Michael Villanueva said Wall faces 18 years without parole if found guilty.

images.alt: Darren Wall, 44, is seen on CCTV attacking a reveler in a nightclub before brandishing a gun during a Valentine's Day date with his wife on February 15, 2022, in Manila, the Philippines.??????Package (video, photos, text)??????Shocking CCTV footage shows a British ???cocaine baron??? attacking a reveler with a pool ball as chilling pictures emerged of him posing with his guns. Notorious thug Darren Wall, 44, was on a Valentine???s Day date with his glamorous wife Khanary Jane Abejo, 23, at the Secret Door nightclub in Manila, the Philippines, when a local ???looked at him the wrong way??? in the early hours of February 15. Darren is seen on camera repeatedly punching the man before hitting him over the head with a pool ball. He was bundled away before removing his sock and putting a ball inside it and returning a second time to smash the man in the face. Cameras outside the nightspot show Darren continuing the rampage by punching another person then brandishing a handgun as he chases him down the street. The alleged gangster from the East London was arrested on March 23 at the same nightclub, leading cops to uncover a ???treasure trove??? of evidence against the ???British psychopath??? which could see him jailed for life. New pictures that police have uncovered show Wall posing menacingly with a handgun while flanked by four Filipino friends. Another shows him laughing with police while others show him on a cinema date with his wife.

Wall said he ???should have slit his throat??? as the former bodyguard later appeared to have later tried to hack into Darren???s Bitcoin cryptocurrency wallets.Outraged Darren said he had looked through his computer???s history to snare the former friend. He is currently waiting for Philippine immigration officials to decide whether he is deported to the ???cushy??? UK or held in a squalid cell in their country to face trial.Officials said that Darren is hoping to return to London and dodge drug trafficking accusations that could reportedly see him jailed for life in the country, which takes a hard-line against illegal substances.

page_details.post_title: British embassy security guard denies spying for Russian government

page_details.article_body:
David Smith was working as a security guard at the embassy in Berlin when the alleged offences were committed (Picture: East2West/PA)A security guard who was stationed at the British embassy in Berlin has denied spying for Russia.
David Smith, 57, pleaded not guilty to nine offences under the Official Secrets Act.
The British national, who was living in Potsdam, is accused of gathering information from the embassy and passing it to someone he believed was a representative of the Russian state.
The alleged offences are supposed to have taken place between October 2020 and August last year.
Mr Smith, 57, was remanded in custody pending his next court date at the Old Bailey on April 13.
He was arrested by German police on August 10 and imprisoned before being extradited to the UK on Wednesday.
British prosecutors allege Mr Smith ‘attempted to communicate’ by letter with ‘General Major Sergey Chukhurov, the Russian military attache based out of the Russian Embassy, Berlin’.
The 57-year-old has pleaded not guilty to nine charges after being extradited from Germany (Picture: East2West)The material ‘contained details about the activities, identities, addresses and telephone numbers of various members of Her Majesty’s Civil Service’, the prosecution alleges.
As well as information on personnel, Mr Smith is accused to collecting material about the operations and layout of the embassy that may have been ‘useful to an enemy’.
He is charged with making unauthorised copies of documents, video recordings of the CCTV system and retaining packaging for SIM cards he had been ask to ‘dispose of’.
Smith is also accused of committing acts ‘prejudicial’ to the safety and interest of the state by gathering information classified as ‘secret’ about the ‘activities of Her Majesty’s Government’.
Mr Smith pleaded not guilty to all nine offences during a short hearing Westminster Magistrates’ Court today.
Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk.

page_details.post_title: Mum’s final kiss for daughter who died after eating ‘cannabis gummy sweet’

page_details.article_body:
Damilola Grace Olakanmi is kissed in hospital by her mother Wumi (Picture: Family handout)Tributes have poured in for a ‘kind and promising’ law student who died after ‘eating a cannabis gummy sweet’. 
Damilola Grace Olakanmi, 23, bought the ‘gummies’ with her friend through a messaging app on her phone last Tuesday and they were delivered to her home.
However, they both immediately fell ill at the house in Illford, east London, after eating just one sweet each.
Ms Olakanmi’s mother Wunmi, 51 kept a vigil by her bedside as she fought for her life in Romford’s Queen’s Hospital, where she died on Saturday. 
A heart-breaking photo shows her kissing her daughter’s head in a final farewell as she lay dying.
Justice campaigner and relative Richard Taylor, 75, consoled the student’s distraught mother on Sunday.
He told the Standard: ‘Wumi has lost her only child – she has nothing now.
Damilola Olakanmi, a 23-year-old law student, bought the ‘gummies’ with her friend through a messaging app on her phone (Picture: BPM Media)‘They had to hold her up because she broke down every time a friend came to the house to give support.
‘It’s a tragic warning to all young people about how they live their lives. They should resist drugs.
‘Damilola was a promising young woman who should be looking forward to her future and having children of her own. She was studying law.’
A relative, named only as Dunni, added the family were demanding answers.
She said: ‘Damilola was a sweet, quiet girl – a bit of an introvert. Her mother looked up to her.
‘She was very kind and loved looking after children and wanted to please everyone. The family will never come to terms with this. We need to know what happened. Her mother is not young anymore.’
Dunni added that she did not want Damilola to be remembered for how she died.
‘You want her to be remembered as the girl who asked everyone, “Are you okay and do you want anything?”.’
Damilola was studying business law at the University of Hertfordshire. 
She was airlifted to hospital in critical condition after eating the sweet, and tragically could not be saved. 
Doctors later discharged Ms Olakanmi’s friend, a US student visiting the UK, from hospital. 
Leon Brown, 37, of South Norwood, was arrested in connection with the incident on Friday.
He was subsequently charged with possession with intent to supply Class B synthetic cannabinoid, being concerned in the supply of a synthetic cannabinoid, and possession with intent to supply a psychoactive substance. 
The death has prompted police to issue a warning not to buy or consume such products.
Chief Superintendent Stuart Bell of the Met’s East Area BCU said: ‘I must warn the public against taking any illegal substances, including those packaged in the form of cannabis sweets.
‘Please do not buy or consume these products. They are illegal and, because of the child-friendly packaging, they can pose a risk of accidental consumption. The particular batch of sweets were contained in packaging featuring ‘Trrlli Peachie O’s’ branding. It has not been confirmed at this stage where the sweets were manufactured.
Drug dealers harm communities and risk the safety of individuals. We will take positive action to target those engaged in this activity as well as those found in possession of these substances.
‘Anyone with information about people selling illegal products such as these is asked to speak with local officers, call police on 101 or, to remain anonymous, contact Crimestoppers.’
 A special post-mortem examination will be arranged in due course, the Met said.
Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk.
For more stories like this, check our news page.

images.alt: The pictures of Damilola Olakanmi, and in hospital with her mum, were sent to the aunt by the victim?s mother Wumi. TRIBUTES have been paid to a ?kind and promising? law student who died after consuming a suspected cannabis sweet in east London. Damilola Olakanmi, 23, bought the ?gummies? via a messaging app on her phone and they were delivered to her home. Ms Olakanmi and a 21-year-old friend immediately fell ill at the mid-terraced house in South Park Drive, Ilford at 11.30pm on Tuesday, March 29. Both ate the sweets which came in packaging branded with ?Trrlli Peachie O?s?.

page_details.post_title: Inside the £25,000,000 superyacht due to set sail in London

page_details.article_body:
The huge ship cost £25million to build (Picture: Oceandiva/Smart Group)Last month we announced the launch of Oceandiva London; a huge yacht built for weddings and parties in the capital.
And now you can peek inside, as renderings of the £25million ship have been released, showing its lavish interiors and expansive rooms.
Launching in the autumn, the Oceandiva is 282ft long and can carry 1,500 guests standing or 600 seated.
It’s clear to see why the vessel is being touted as the ‘largest floating events space’ on the Thames, boasting three decks and amenities like a bar and dancefloor.
Pictures show a swanky bar decked out in black marble and chrome, where ‘London’s leading mixologists’ will be on hand to ensure your guests are topped up.
There’s also a large dancefloor and stage, lit with spotlights and an LED wall. This is presumably where the superyacht will play host to ‘glamourous high-profile events for private and corporate celebrations, fashion and film shoots, launches, milestone birthdays, and cultural celebrations.’
Newly-released renderings show the vessel’s interior (Picture: Oceandiva/Smart Group)Oceandiva London will play host to conferences, weddings, and large parties (Picture: Oceandiva/Smart Group)If food is more your thing, you’ll be spoilt for choice. The caterers on board can  count the likes of Gucci and Kensington Palace as previous clients, and will be serving dishes based on local and seasonal ingredients.
Canapes like treacle-cured salmon with caviar or ‘bowl food’ like steak tartare with chips, cured egg, and mustard are on the menu for casual soirees, while sit-down options include short rib served with sweet potato and parmesan, followed by mango, lime and coconut tart for dessert.
Expansive rooms with dancefloors and stages can be spotted throughout (Picture: Oceandiva/Smart Group)Guests will sail past landmarks like Tower Bridge and Big Ben (Picture: Oceandiva/Smart Group)Managed as part of a collaboration between Dutch company Oceandiva and British events business Smart Group, the floating venue is marketed towards a ‘discerning party host [who is] keen to wow their guests’.
Guests can board at one of six docking stations across London – Butler’s Wharf, London Bridge, Tower Bridge, Canary Wharf, Greenwich and Royal Victoria Dock – before travelling past landmarks like Tower Bridge and Big Ben. 
Although superyachts have a bit of a bad rap, Oceandiva London can’t be faulted on its eco credentials. The ship is CO2-neutral ship will be powered by solar panels and Lithium battery packs that are charged by a green power connection on the shore.
Despite its size, the Oceandiva is actually completely CO2 neutral (Picture: Oceandiva/Smart Group)Up to 1,500 people can be carried across three decks (Picture: Oceandiva/Smart Group)Edwin Petersen, CEO of Oceandiva, said: ‘We have had great success in the Netherlands and Germany so we are incredibly excited to launch our first concept in London which we believe will be the hottest venue in the capital for the most lavish celebrations.
‘London is undeniably one of the most attractive cities for overseas visitors and we are looking forward to hosting extraordinary celebrations on board.’
More: TravelInside the Maldives' first resort as the country celebrates 50 years of tourism
Underwater art and rooftop pool parties: Your travel guide to Miami, Florida
Quirky trips and experiences to book this EasterGreg Lawson, the CEO of Smart Group commented: ‘We are excited to bring a stylish new events space to London, one that raises the bar for luxury venues for private celebrations.’
Prices for events on Oceandiva haven’t been released, but we can’t imagine it’ll be cheap to hire. If you’re after a unique venue and have cash to splash, though, it’s bound to impress.
Do you have a story to share?
Get in touch by emailing MetroLifestyleTeam@Metro.co.uk.

page_details.post_title: Who is this woman and what has she done with Denise Welch? Loose Women star unrecognisable with blonde wig and filter

page_details.article_body:
Denise looked a far cry from her usual self (Picture: ITV/REX/Shutterstock/Instagram)Who is this woman and what has she done with Denise Welch, please?
The Loose Women star, 63, has been playing around with wigs and filters and looks genuinely unrecognisable in her latest Instagram post.
Swapping her trademark short hairdo for a longer blonde wig, she donned some bright peach and pink clothes and a pair of very fetching glasses.
‘Playing around with wigs and a ‘smidge’ of a filter with @glambypamelab,’ she wrote.
‘I now feel the need for an ‘interview look’ every time I go to the bloody shops!!! 💄💋💅😎🥵🥵🥵.’
Denise’s husband Lincoln Townley was particularly impressed, writing: ‘I’m having that WIG @denise_welch IMMEDIATELY.’
Get in line, Lincoln! 
Talk about shapeshifting Denise… (Picture: Instagram/Denise Welch)Fans couldn’t believe it either, with one writing: ‘Doesn’t even look like u!!! Wow 👏’, while another added: ‘Looking good in the disguise x’.
The snap came after Denise attended the GLAAD Awards this week, looking a little more herself in a sparkly red jacket with matching heels and lippie.
‘@glaad awards celebrates the media who show inclusion & representation of the LGBGTQ community in Hollywood,’ she wrote on Instagram.
Lincoln has his eye on the wig (Picture: WireImage)‘I was proud to be there as an ally & will be posting a million more photos when I wake up!!!’
Meanwhile, she also recently celebrated International Women’s Day with the rest of the ITV daytime ladies, with the gang taking an adorable snap.
More: Loose WomenBrenda Edwards shares beautiful family pictures of late son Jamal Edwards on Mother’s Day
Strictly star Johannes Radebe now ready for love after battling 'internalised homophobia'
Nadia Sawalha leads Loose Women tributes to late EastEnders legend June BrownIn the official pictures Rochelle Humes, Alison Hammond, Linda Robson and the rest of the crew were seen smiling from ear to ear while dressed in various shades of red, pink, maroon and orange to mark the occasion.
Sophie Morgan, Susanna Reid, Charlene White, Charlotte Hawkins, Josie Gibson, Nadia Sawalha, Laura Tobin, Janet Street-Porter, Gloria Hunniford, Kelle Bryan, Katie Piper, Christine Lampard, Ranvir Singh, and Penny Lancaster also completed the star-studded lineup.
Got a story?
If you’ve got a celebrity story, video or pictures get in touch with the Metro.co.uk entertainment team by emailing us celebtips@metro.co.uk, calling 020 3615 2145 or by visiting our Submit Stuff page – we’d love to hear from you.

page_details.post_title: Councillors ditch meeting with vegan food for pub lunch at Slug and Lettuce

page_details.article_body:
The vegan buffet got a mixed reaction from councillors some loved it while others chose to go to the pub instead (Picture: @_LiamWalker_/@IanMiddletonX)A group of councillors ditched a taxpayer-funded vegan buffet in favour of a pub lunch at Slug and Lettuce.
Liam Walker says he and around 15 of his colleagues snubbed the meat-free offering at Oxfordshire County Council earlier this week ‘on principle’.
Oxfordshire councillors approved a motion proposing all food served at council catered events be plant-based last month.
The first council-catered meeting with a fully vegan offering took place on Tuesday but the lavish buffet received a mixed reaction.
Some loved the spread and tweeted their approval, while others boycotted the meal in favour of pub lunch and its meat options.
Mr Walker was among those to walk away from the vegan buffet, dubbing the fare a ‘waste of taxpayers’ money’.
‘I think this new alliance have completely misread the room,’ he said.
‘Now they are boasting on Twitter about a vegan taxpayer-funded buffet at council meetings.
‘I’m all for veganism but we live in a democracy so should have freedom of choice. 
The vegan buffet on offer at Oxford County Council’s full meeting on Tuesday (Picture: @IanMiddletonX)One councillor hailed the vegan spread ‘a triumph’ (Picture: @IanMiddletonX)Mr Walker said he believed ‘free meals’ at the council meetings ‘should be scrapped’ and said neither he nor his colleagues would be claiming their pub lunch on expenses.
‘Taking a step back I don’t think we should serve councillors free food altogether,’ he said.
‘The fact that people this year have the difficult choice between eating and heating shows how out of touch it is.
‘As councillors, we are perfectly capable of arranging our own lunches.
‘This is a complete waste of money.
‘The coalition should be focused on tackling the serious issues in Oxfordshire like supporting the many residents struggling with food and heating bills.’
Councillor Liam Walker said he left the buffet ‘on principle’ (Picture: Liam Walker / SWNS)Mr Walker also hit out at the fact the council food was ‘clearly’ not locally sourced.
‘Last time I checked we don’t grow melons in Oxfordshire,’ he added.
However, Green Party councillor Ian Middleton hailed the buffet ‘a triumph’.
Sharing pictures of the spread on Twitter Mr Middleton said: ‘First plant based lunch at Oxford County Council very enthusiastically received. 
‘Some saying it’s the best food that has ever been provided by the council. Thanks to officers for organising it. An absolute triumph!’
First #plantbased lunch at @OxfordshireCC very enthusiastically received. Some saying it’s the best food that has ever been provided by the council. Thanks to officers for organising it. An absolute triumph! pic.twitter.com/o0acCvnJcL— Ian Middleton ðºð¦ (@IanMiddletonX) April 5, 2022In response to criticisms of its plant-based offering Oxfordshire County Council said the vegan buffet was ‘endorsed by cabinet in March’.
It said there were seven full council meetings a year at which elected officials were provided with food.
‘[Tuesday’s] meeting was the first since the policy was endorsed by cabinet in March,’ the council said.
‘Councils all over the country provide lunch when all-day formal council meetings take place.
‘Plans for future meetings have yet to be discussed and alternative suppliers may be explored.
‘The policy is framed by the need to tackle climate change, reduce food waste and support healthy eating in line with the county council being the local authority with responsibility for public health.’
Get in touch with our news team by emailing us at webnews@metro.co.uk.

page_details.post_title: These are the six core personality traits that highly sensitive people possess, says study

page_details.article_body:
Four of them are very positive attributes (Picture: Getty)Highly sensitive people can get a lot of stick – often labelled as ‘too emotional’ or someone who ‘overreacts’ to things.
But a new study has found that they actually have numerous positive personality traits.
In fact, of the six key traits that make up a highly sensitive person, four of them are widely considered to be incredibly beneficial attributes.
The new research – which was published in the Journal Of Personality Assessment – asked 10,300 participants aged 18 to 87 to respond to a draft questionnaire, based on 60 traits they identified in other studies on the subject. 
After getting this data back, researchers noticed 43 common qualities – which they then grouped into six factors that make up a highly sensitive person (HSP).
Sensory and aesthetic sensitivity are two of them (Picture: Getty)The first one was emotional and physiological reactivity – AKA being ‘too sensitive’ – so a tendency to get upset by external factors.
Sensory discomfort was the second attribute – so being bothered by certain smells, sounds or lights. 
The third is social-affective sensitivity, which means being a good reader of other people’s emotions. 
Next up is sensory sensitively, which refers to being aware when something changes in your body – and being in touch with your own health.
There’s then sensory comfort and pleasure, which means taking pleasure in nice feelings such as love, joy and relaxation.
The final trait is aesthetic sensitivity – so being able to appreciate art, music and nature on a deeper and more emotional level.
More: LifestyleWhy is delayed gratification so hot?
How to ask your landlord to let you do DIY in a rented home
Firefighters cut woman's stuck wedding ring off as her finger began to turn blue				What are the six traits of highly sensitive people?			Emotional and physiological reactivity 
Sensory discomfort
Social-affective sensitivity
Sensory sensitivity
Sensory comfort and pleasure
Aesthetic sensitivity 
The final four traits are widely considered important and good ones to have – as people with these are often in touch with themselves and the world around them, with high emotional intelligence. 
Equally, highly sensitive people often face issues linked to the first two listed.
However, the research is an important reminder of the benefits of being a HSP.
Do you have a story to share?
Get in touch by emailing MetroLifestyleTeam@Metro.co.uk.
